Award.AwardTitle: New Constraints on Size-resolved Submicron Sea-salt Particle Production from Ocean Breaking Waves
Award.AbstractNarration:
Marine aerosols play an important role in controlling the Earth's radiation balance, cloud formation and microphysics. One particular knowledge gap in sea spray aerosol emissions resides in the incompletely characterized contribution of sea-salt to the cloud condensation nuclei (CCN) budget in the marine boundary layer (MBL). The chemical composition of 50 to 200 nm sized sea spray particles, most critical to climate models, is variously described as purely organic, purely sea-salt or mixtures of both. The production fluxes of these sub-micron particles is of particular interest. This project will help developing improved parameterizations for size- and composition-dependent production fluxes of sea spray particles needed to constrain the CCN fluxes of natural aerosols in regional and climate models.

North Carolina State University (NCSU) investigators will deploy a relaxed eddy accumulation (REA) flux system specifically designed to measure turbulent fluxes of size-resolved dry sea-salt (inner) cores. The REA-S flux system will be deployed at the U.S. Army Corps of
Engineers (USACE) 560 m long research pier facility at Duck, NC, chosen to sample representative MBL conditions.

A ship based environmental education program designed for secondary and high school students and their teachers, and development of university and K-12 learning materials and curricula that integrate data analysis into classroom instruction will be used. A goal of this is for increased understanding of factors affecting atmospheric and marine science processes as related to cloud formation and subsequent effects on climate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Accurate prediction of future climate is one of the vital issues facing our society. The most recent scientific, technical, and socio-economic information available to researchers worldwide suggests that changing climate could lead to increased frequency and intensity of extreme events such as floods, landslides, droughts, and fires. Climate change will also cause prolonged negative effects related to the rise of sea levels, intensification of coastal erosion, increase in heat waves, and worsening of air and water quality. Such processes will have adverse effects on human health, the distribution of natural resources and, above other things, will inevitably lead to security challenges for the nations. Predictions of future climate are based on elaborate numerical computer models that treat our earth system (the atmosphere, biosphere, hydrosphere, and lithosphere) in a holistic way. However, models are not flawless, and their perfection is ultimately tied to improvements in our understanding of the natural processes and ability to make complex measurements for model verification. 

One of such measurements is a number concentration of sea salt particles over the ocean. A good knowledge of the natural background levels of particles is extremely important because it helps the climate models to make improved predictions of human-induced effects. In this project, we designed and built a new instrument capable of measuring size-resolved sea salt particle fluxes through a continuous flow hygroscopicity-resolved relaxed eddy accumulation (Hy-Res REA) technique. We have also developed a new methodology for the particle flux and hygroscopicity measurements. The different components of the instrument were extensively tested inside the US Environmental Protection Agency’s Aerosol Test Facility. The instrument was field-deployed during Fall 2015 and Spring 2016 intensive campaigns at the US Army Corps of Engineers’ Field Research Facility (FRF) in Duck, NC. The system was also deployed onboard of NOAA Ship Hi'ialakaiat theWoods Hole Oceanographic Institution Hawaii Ocean Timeseries Station in summer 2016. Analysis of our results revealed that on average, sea salt contributes only a small fraction (<10%) of particles found in the marine boundary layer. This is a very important result because it suggests that the effect of anthropogenic emissions on the energy budget of the Earth may be bigger than scientists originally thought. The results of this study were disseminated through 4 (plus one in preparation) peer-reviewed publication and over 15 presentations in national and international conferences.

The grant has supported the professional development and training of a Ph.D. student (now works at NASA Langley) and two M.S. students (one is pursuing his Ph.D. at The University of Tennessee, Knoxville and the other works as Product Design Engineer at Denso Manufacturing). Results of this study were used in the development of learning materials engaging children at West Millbrook Middle School, Baileywick Road Elementary School, and the imagination station science museum summer scholars program. Results of this study were also used in our Floating Classroom Program to educate citizens about the carbon cycle and climate change. This program, developed on the research vessel, the R/V Humphries(formerly a Coast Guard auxiliary patrol boat), has been extremely popular over the past several years. It offers hands-on experiences in educating young people (secondary and high school age) and their teachers about the factors that influence estuarine water quality and aquatic communities. Students have also learned various tools used to identify, characterize, and manage the state’s water resources.
